Thank you, Comptroller Hsu, for taking up the issue of climate change and banks. 
Even as banks publicly claim to be taking climate change seriously and phasing out financing for greenhouse gas emissions, they are investing billions into companies that produce fossil fuels. Banks' continued investments in fossil fuels are driving climate change – a crisis that puts our financial system, people of color and low-income communities, and our planet at risk. 
Regulators must not let financial institutions gamble with our future. We need you to push banks to take the urgent steps necessary to address the dangers they face from climate change, and stop their short-term business decisions from endangering our economy and communities.
I support the proposed guidance’s recommendations to banks that they:
Incorporate climate-related risk management into every level of business;
Plan for climate change over a long time horizon, and update models as additional data becomes available;
Develop clear definitions of possible climate-related risk exposures, and metrics for setting limits; 
And make sure that their internal strategies are consistent with their public-facing climate commitments.
The OCC must ensure that banks’ actions match their commitments to zeroing out their net carbon emissions. Banks’ management of climate risk should be factored into their supervisory ratings, too.
It is in the best interest of both the public and banks themselves to act now to minimize climate risk. The OCC must use the full extent of its authority to issue strong final guidance to banks on climate risk, continue to protect against unsafe and unsound bank practices, and require remedies from banks where appropriate.
The actions outlined above can go a long way toward protecting the American people and the banks themselves as we transition to a future that does not rely on fossil fuels.
There is no better time than now.

comment: Dear Comptroller Hsu, As an organization guided by the Quaker belief in the divine light within each person, the American Friends Service Committee (AFSC) works to promote a world free of violence, inequality, and oppression. As such, we cannot ignore the pressing threats that climate change poses to the most vulnerable communities on the earth. We cannot ignore the ways that ongoing fossil fuel financing by big banks bolsters the affluence of the rich and powerful at the expense of our collective well-being.  At AFSC, multiple programs work towards just and sustainable peace, just economies, and a just response to forces displacement and migration. In this work, a lens of climate justice informs our efforts. We see climate change as a root cause for myriad issues facing our society. Climate change is a driver of violence, socio-economic disruption, and displacement. Thank you, Comptroller Hsu, for taking up the issue of climate change and banks. Even as banks publicly claim to be taking climate change seriously and phasing out financing for greenhouse gas emissions, they are investing billions into companies that produce fossil fuels. Since the Paris Agreement was signed in 2015, the largest banks have invested more than $3.8 trillion in oil, gas, and coal production. JPMorgan Chase, Chase, Wells Fargo and Bank of America have loaned more money to the fossil fuel industry than any other banks in the world. Banks’ continued investments in fossil fuels are driving climate change – a crisis that puts our financial system, people of color and low-income communities, and our planet at risk. AFSC programs across the country and the world work with vulnerable communities to support dignity and justice for all. Our communities are seeing firsthand the effects of climate change on their local environments and the ways that these changes are exacerbating inequality across regions and borders. Drought in New Mexico and California is threatening food security and causing heat exhaustion in workers. Drought in the MENA region is intensifying conflict over water and arable land. Hurricanes in Central America are destroying infrastructure and displacing families.  AFSC has a long history of advancing peace and justice through economic activism. Throughout the twentieth century and into the twenty-first, AFSC has reckoned with how our possessions and our capital are tied to injustice,  and in the context of our modern financial system, how socially responsible investing and shareholder advocacy can drive change that prioritizes people over profits. In accordance with this mission, at AFSC we operate on a socially responsible investment policy that strengthens and expands divestment from prisons, militarism, border industry, apartheid, and environmental devastation.  On Earth Day 2019, recognizing the social impact of climate change on the communities we work with and the Quaker commitment to good stewardship of resources, AFSC announced its divestment from the fossil fuel industry.  Comptroller Hsu, we need you to recognize the power that financial institutions hold in either protecting or destroying the environment that we all depend on. We need you to take the urgent steps necessary to address the dangers we face from climate change and stop big banks’ short-term business decisions from endangering our economy and communities. We support the proposed guidance’s recommendations to banks that they: 1. Incorporate climate-related risk management into every level of business; 2. Plan for climate change over a long time horizon and update models as additional data becomes available; 3. Develop clear definitions of possible climate-related risk exposures and metrics for setting limits; 4. Make sure that their internal strategies are consistent with their public-facing climate commitments. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) must ensure that banks’ actions match their commitments to zeroing out their net carbon emissions. Banks’ management of climate risk should be factored into their supervisory ratings as well. It is in the best interest of both the public and banks themselves to act now to minimize climate risk. The OCC must use the full extent of its authority to issue strong final guidance to banks on climate risk, continue to protect against unsafe and unsound bank practices, and require remedies from banks where appropriate. Climate change is here, and its drivers are not unknown or untouchable. Financial institutions that continue to facilitate the exploitation of natural resources and the burning of fossil fuels are prioritizing their profits over our collective futures. We must hold them accountable. Comptroller Hsu, please use the full extent of your authority to curtail banks’ investments in climate change, for the future of our economy and our planet.
